dataset.shortName: California Current Ecosystem Biological and Physical Water Column Properties - Annual Averages
dataset.title: Annual cruise data averages of physical and biological water column properties in the Southern California Bight (temperature, salinity, density, chlorophyll, integrated cholorphyll, phosphate, silicic acid, nitrite, nitrate, primary production, mixed layer depth, and nitrocline depth.

creator.organizationName: California Current Ecosystem Long - Term Ecological Research Program

intellectualRights.para: Citation acknowledgement: Data from the California Current Ecosystem LTER data repository were supported by funding sources

section.title: abstract
section.para: Water column bottle sample data averaged across up to 46 standard stations (inshore and offshore) per cruise and then averaged over a varying number of cruises in any one year to give an annual average.

section.title: methods
section.para: The mixed layer depth was taken to be the larger of either a) 12 m or b) the depth where the density gradient for the first time (descending through the water column from the surface) was larger than 0.002 kg/m4. Station Mixed Layer Average: The mixed layer averages were calculated by averaging all data for any one parameter collected in the mixed layer, ie there is one resultant value for any one parameter per station. Cruise Averages: Station Mixed Layer Averages were averages for up to 46 standard stations. Annual Averages: Station Mixed Layer Averages were averaged for all cruises and up to 46 standard stations for any one year. Nitrocline Depth: The depth at which the concentration of nitrate reacher 1 microMole. See DataZoo dataset #82.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Sampling takes place west of California. Sampling arrangements include use of the CalCOFI fixed grid of stations located within the Southern California Bight along offshore transects from San Diego to Point Conception and use of moving stations centered on drifters or drogues.

section.title: Geographic Description
section.para: Southern California Bight inshore and nearshore

project.title: California Current Ecosystem Long-Term Ecological Research Program

abstract.para: The California Current Ecosystem program is a member site of the Long-Term Ecological Research program, a network of sites investigating diverse biomes. A team of researchers is investigating nonlinear transitions in the California Current coastal pelagic ecosystem, with particular attention to long-term forcing by a secular warming trend, the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, and El Nino in altering the structure and dynamics of the pelagic ecosystem. The California Current System is a coastal upwelling biome, as found along the eastern margins of all major ocean basins. These are among the most productive ecosystems in the world ocean. The California Current sustains active fisheries for a variety of finfish and marine invertebrates, modulates weather patterns and the hydrologic cycle of much of the western United States, and plays a vital role in the economy of myriad coastal communities.
